Award.AwardTitle: Theoretical Development of Nonlinear Surface-Selective Spectroscopies of Hydrogen-Bonded Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Vladimir Chernyak of Wayne State University is supported by an award from the Theoretical and Computational Chemistry program for research to develop methods to characterize surface-selective spectroscopic information, particularly for hydrogen-bonded systems. The work is specifically focused on the development of models for ultrafast dynamics of these systems and includes: (i) the development and validation of time-resolved, even-order nonlinear spectroscopic techniques capable of background-free detection of the surface signal; (ii) development of efficient signal processing algorithms; and (iii) development of reduced-dimensionality classical and semi-classical stochastic models for ultrafast dynamics including quantum effects.

Hydrogen bonding is one of the fundamental non-covalent interactions that occur in chemistry and biology and is responsible for many unique properties of molecular assemblies. Understanding the general dynamical features of complex hydrogen-bonded systems will help us understand biomolecular systems in general and will also aid in developing new technological applications that rest on an improved understanding of this important chemical interaction. The theoretical approaches and methods for processing experimental data that are being developed in this work are critical for interpreting experiments but may also be extended to other types of studies such as single-molecule spectroscopy, optical fiber communications and light and energy conversion in a variety of technological applications. Chernyak is involving under-represented minority high school students in his research group through a "High School Student Apprentice Program" run by the Detroit Public School System. The work is, thus, having a broader impact both on the development of new technology and on the training of a diverse scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Large organic molecules and conjugated structures constitute a class of materials that are interesting both from the fundamental research viewpoint, as well as for practical applications. The fundamental character of organic systems is due to a small number of building blocks (mostly carbon, hydrogen and oxygen atoms) with a huge variety in their chemical, photochemical, and dynamical properties, depending on the connectivity. Due to the overlap between atomic orbitals, the single-electron states in organic systems are delocalized over the entire molecule, and electrons participate in Coulomb interactions with each other, with the correlation effects being particularly strong due to the molecule low (quasi-one)-dimensional geometry. Precise quantum chemistry computations in large organic molecules are not feasible, due to unfavorable scaling of the numerical effort with the system size. We have developed a multiscale approach, coined the Exciton Scattering (ES) method that combines a capability to perform precise calculations of the excited state electronic structure and optical/spectroscopic properties in branched conjugated structures of practically unlimited size with providing a microscopic insight into the structure of electronic excitations (excitons). Within the ES approach electronic excitations are treated as standing waves that reside on the linear segments of a branched molecule, and are formed as a result of scattering on branching centers (including the molecule termini). The excitation properties are obtained by solving the ES equations, with the numerical effort scaling with the number of linear segments in the structure, rather than the number of atomic orbitals, and therefore calculations can be readily performed for the structures that contain thousands of carbon atoms. The input for the ES calculations, i.e., the excitons spectra and scattering matrices can be obtained from quantum chemistry computations in small molecular fragments where quantum chemistry is still feasible. 

Biological molecules, such as molecular motors that perform in stochastic (random) environment are still capable of providing robust functionality. We have studied the performance of such systems under periodic (cyclic) slow driving in the low-noise limit. We have demonstrated that in the limit described above the system dynamics is of topological nature, i.e., the performance is robust with respect to moderate changes in the driving protocol and random fluctuations due to the environment, and is characterized by integer or rational (fractional numbers). A molecular machine is modeled by a network with its nodes describing the molecule’s meta-stable states (confirmations), with the links representing the transition pathways. We have also developed a set of fast approximate algorithms that allow inference problems (i.e., extracting information corrupted by noise) in networks to be treated in an efficient way. 

On the broader impact side, the microscopic insight into excited state electronic structure and optical/spectroscopic properties of conjugated system will assist in developing and engineering of inexpensive organic-based photovoltaic materials, in particular with applications to efficient solar energy conversion. The link between non-equilibrium statistical mechanics and algebraic topology, identified in studying the low-temperature adiabatic limit of the performance of cyclically driven molecular motors can open new ways to study delicate topological invariants of smooth manifolds, using methods of statistical physics. Our studies of graphical models that describe networks should have important implications on the algorithm theory and information science, including statistical inference and development of favorably scaling approximate classical and quantum algorithms for hard problems.
